# Using Base Nodes to Lay Out SpriteKit Content

**Article**

Use nonvisual nodes to define the layout of a scene.

## Overview

Each onscreen element in SpriteKit is referred to as a *node*. Nodes are either visual elements or containers of other nodes. You set up the appearance of a SpriteKit scene by adding nodes alongside and on top of each other in a hierarchical form. Collectively, this structure is referred to as the *node tree* or the *node hierarchy*.

These are the basic nonvisual nodes in SpriteKit:

- [doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/SpriteKit/SKNode] is a container node. It doesn’t render any content of its own, but works as a layout tool for its child nodes.
- [doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/SpriteKit/SKReferenceNode] doesn’t define content of its own, but refers to another node or archived file that does.
- [doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/SpriteKit/SKCameraNode] defines point of view within a scene. Its inverse scale is applied to all nodes in the hierarchy except for its children. Use the children of `SKCameraNode` for UI elements that should be unaffected by zoom level.

For a list of visual elements, see Nodes that Draw in [doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/SpriteKit/nodes-for-scene-building], which also includes some examples of using visual nodes.

## Base Nodes

- **SKNode**: The base class of all SpriteKit nodes.
- **SKCameraNode**: A node that determines which parts of the scene are visible within a view.
- **SKReferenceNode**: A node that’s defined in an archived `.sks` file.
